title: 104_hr4069
content: The Act titled "Graduate Medical Education Trust Fund Act of 1996" amends the Social Security Act to establish a Teaching Hospital and Graduate Medical Education Trust Fund. This fund is created under Title XXI and includes the establishment of a fund according to Section 2101. The Teaching Hospital and Graduate Medical Education Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, consisting of transferred amounts, appropriations, and gifts. The Fund is available for expenditures by the Secretary for payments under section 2111, with transfers from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund determined annually by the Secretary. The Secretary determines the amounts for the fiscal year based on estimates, allocating funds between Medicare trust funds. The Secretary allocates funds between Medicare trust funds based on the proportion of payments for medical education costs of hospitals under each respective part. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1997 through 2003, with investments made in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Fund may acquire obligations of the United States on original issue or by purchase, and sell them at market price. Any interest and proceeds from sales are appropriated to the Fund. The Fund can also accept money gifts and bequests unconditionally for its benefit or financed activities. "Formula payments to teaching hospitals are outlined in Section 2111." The Secretary will make payments to teaching hospitals for the costs of operating medical residency training programs based on a formula established by the Secretary. Payment documents must be submitted in a specified form and manner by a certain date. The Secretary may require information to be submitted in periodic reports for adjustments in Medicare payments, excluding medical education and disproportionate share hospital payments from the calculation of adjusted average per capita cost. The Secretary may authorize supplemental payments to hospitals for payment adjustments under section 1886(d)(5)(F) and for indirect or direct graduate medical education costs under section 1886(d)(5)(B) and 1886(h) respectively, beginning in fiscal year 1998. The Secretary may authorize supplemental payments to hospitals for payment adjustments and graduate medical education costs, not exceeding 75 percent of the reductions in payments under section 1876. The National Advisory Council on Postgraduate Medical Education is established. The National Advisory Council on Postgraduate Medical Education, established within the Department of Health and Human Services, provides advice to the Secretary on policies for supporting postgraduate medical education to ensure an adequate supply of physicians in various specialties. The Council is composed of 15 individuals appointed by the Secretary, including representation from organizations representing consumers of healthcare services. The National Advisory Council on Postgraduate Medical Education advises the Secretary on policies for supporting postgraduate medical education. It includes representatives from organizations related to healthcare services, medical schools, teaching hospitals, and accrediting bodies like the Accreditation Council on Graduate Medical Education. Other members are physicians, practitioners in public health, advanced-practice nurses, and other health professionals. The Council on Podiatric Medical Education of the American Podiatric Medical Association aims to have a diverse membership representing various regions, demographics, and medical institutions in the US. Ex officio members may include federal officers appointed by the President or Secretary. The Council on Podiatric Medical Education of the American Podiatric Medical Association includes federal officers appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, such as the Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Veterans Affairs, and Defense. The Secretary designates a chair from council members, and the Council terminates on December 31, 2000.
